0.user_question: Two candidates, Dan and Donald, run for class president. Two other candidates, Freddie and Bernie, run for vice president. Each candidate has a 50$\%$ chance of winning. What is the probability that both Dan and Freddie win? (Express your answer as a fraction.)

ost_step.1: There are four possible outcomes when electing one president and one vice president:

direct_answer.text: There are four people running for office -- three candidates for president ($Dan$, $Donald$) and two candidates for vice presidency ($Freddie$, $Bernie$). That makes sixteen different ways election results could turn out ($\binom{4}{1}*\binom{3}{1}=6$), since either one person fills each position; i.e., "$\binom{4}{1}\times \binom{3}{1}$". Half those possibilities give us what you seek - namely: President Daniel & Vice President Freddie OR President Donald & Vice President Freddie ; thus our required outcome count equals 3 ("six divided into twos"). To express it mathematically using fractions/probability notation: $$\dfrac{3}{\binom{4}{1}\cdot \binom{3}{1}}= \dfrac{3}{6}= \dfrac{1}{2}$$ Hence the correct choice among options available would definitely be 'C'. Thus, The Answer Is: \(\frac{1}{2}\).

0.user_question: Two candidates, Dan and Donald, run for class president. Two other candidates, Freddie and Bernie, run for vice president. Each candidate has a 50$\%$ chance of winning. What is the probability that both Dan and Freddie win? (Express your answer as a fraction.)

direct_answer.text: There are four possible pairs of winners: DF, DB, FB, BD. For each pair, one person wins while another loses. There are therefore six equally likely ways someone could become either President or Vice President; thus it’s reasonable to assume any particular combination occurs half the time. Hence, P($\text{Dan} \, \& \text { Freddie }$) = P($\text{DF}$)/6 = ${1}/{6}$. To express our solution using just fractions without relying on reasoning about what “half” looks like relative to some imaginary set of possibilities, let us use combinatorics instead. Our sample space consists of ${4}\choose{2}$ ={4*3/2}=6 different ordered outcomes — we choose exactly 2 people who obtain positions among them without regard to order. Out of those six potential combinations, precisely one yields Daniel & Frederick victorious⁠ : the first such possibility would involve selecting Deacon first followed immediately by Fredrick – that corresponds to outcome ’DF.’ Thus Probability({DF}) =$ {\displaystyle {1\over6}}$. The answer is: \frac{1}{6}

subanswer.text: There are ${4 \choose 1 }=4$ such cases since any single candidate could have won while three did not vote or were rejected. The answer is 4.

0.user_question: Two candidates, Dan and Donald, run for class president. Two other candidates, Freddie and Bernie, run for vice president. Each candidate has a 50$\%$ chance of winning. What is the probability that both Dan and Freddie win? (Express your answer as a fraction.)

ost_step.1: There are four possible outcomes when electing one president and one vice president:
ost_step.2: If Dan wins election for President, he could pair up with any of the three running VP candidates ($B$, $F$, or another third unnamed person): $$Dan\text{ }\Pr(\Pr)=\tfrac{1}{2}\cdot \tfrac{1}{2}= \tfrac{1}{4}$$
ost_step.3: Similarly, since each candidate also has a $\tfrac{1}{2}$chance of being elected Vice President regardless who was chosen as Presidency winner; $$\Pr(\vartriangle )= \tfrac{1}{2}\cdot \tfrac{1}{2} =\tfrac {1}{4}$$

direct_answer.text: Let's think step by step. To calculate the probability that both Dan and Freddie win, we multiply the probabilities of them winning individually because the events are independent. Both Dan and Freddie have a 50% chance of winning. Thus, the probability that both Daniel and Frederick win is $(\frac{1}{2}) (\frac{1}{2}) = \frac{1}{4}$. The answer is: \frac{1}{4}.

0.user_question: Two candidates, Dan and Donald, run for class president. Two other candidates, Freddie and Bernie, run for vice president. Each candidate has a 50$\%$ chance of winning. What is the probability that both Dan and Freddie win? (Express your answer as a fraction.)

direct_answer.text: There are four possible pairs of winners: DF, DB, FB, BD. For each pair, one person wins while another loses. There are therefore six equally likely ways someone could become either President or Vice President; thus it’s reasonable to assume any particular combination occurs half the time. Hence, P($\text{Dan} \, \& \text { Freddie }$) = P($\text{DF}$)/6 = ${1}/{6}$. To express our solution using just fractions without relying on reasoning about what “half” looks like relative to some imaginary set of possibilities, let us use combinatorics instead. Our sample space consists of ${4}\choose{2}$ ={4*3/2}=6 different ordered outcomes — we choose exactly 2 people who obtain positions among them without regard to order. Out of those six potential combinations, precisely one yields Daniel & Frederick victorious⁠ : the first such possibility would involve selecting Deacon first followed immediately by Fredrick – that corresponds to outcome ’DF.’ Thus Probability({DF}) =$ {\displaystyle {1\over6}}$. The answer is: \frac{1}{6}

0.user_question: Two candidates, Dan and Donald, run for class president. Two other candidates, Freddie and Bernie, run for vice president. Each candidate has a 50$\%$ chance of winning. What is the probability that both Dan and Freddie win? (Express your answer as a fraction.)

1.subquestion: In how many possible election scenarios exist where only one person wins their position?

subanswer.text: There are ${4 \choose 1 }=4$ such cases since any single candidate could have won while three did not vote or were rejected. The answer is 4.

2.subquestion: In how many different elections does just Donald lose but neither he nor Bob gets elected ?

subanswer.text: This occurs if either Freddie ($F$) loses but otherwise everyone else voted so the scenario must also include someone getting elected who isn't Daniel ("D"). Thus {$(FD),\, FDB,\, BDF$} which totals $3$ possibilities here; note however the order doesn’t matter so they should really count once instead of thrice! Therefore ,therefore$$P(\text{just Donald losing}) = {{3}\over{4}}\times \frac{1}{2}\times \frac{1}{2}={{3}\over{8}}.$$ The answer is $\frac{3}{8}$.

3.subquestion: In how many different elections does nobody except Bobby fail to receive votes OR everybody receives at least 1 vote AND no pair among them received more than half plus another vote i.e., total support greater than equal to <half+one&gt ;?

subanswer.text: Let A mean “Dan didn’t receive enough”,B meaning”Donald didn’t recieve enought,”C means“Bernie wasn’t picked.” Then AA BB CC would satisfy our conditions – thus yielding $$\begin{array}{|c|c|c|c||c|}\hline Election & Abby | AbBob | ABC \\ P(Evenhood) &&&&\\\hline{}AABBCC &= \dfrac{1}{4}({{1}\over{3}}(1-\frac{1}{2})+\frac{1}{3}(\frac{1}{2})^2)\ &=\tfrac{1}{24}\\ {}AABBCC&= \tfrac{1}{8}&&\end{array}$$ So $$P(at\ most\space .5\%)=\tfrac{1}{24}+\tfrac{1}{8}=\tfrac{1}{6}\,,\quad\,\,P({\geq\space .5\%})=\tfrac{5}{6}.$$ The answer is $\tfrac{1}{6}$, hence $$\begin{array}{ccccc} &\textbf{"At least.}" &{:}"One"} &{:}'Two'} &{:}"Three'"\cr&"\bullet\;  5/6."&\mid&\bullet\;   1/6.&\;\mid\;\bigcirc\;    0/\infty\\\hline& "\bullet;""None"; ""Zero""}{\color{red}{(A)}\bullet \;"More Than."}\cr&":":":::"\cr&"\bullet\;      0/"0"&\mid\bullet\;     0/∞&\;\mid\;         {\color{blue}{\bullet\;         5/6.}}\end{array}$$ Note though I chose those choices arbitrarily because having "${\large{.}}$", "${\large{<}}$,"+","*," etcetera being red font seems like kind of silly.. :-P Maybe put some sort of bulletpoint underneath indicating its purpose too... Also adding "(?)?" around fractions sounds interesting.My bad about using my own arbitrary decisions regarding colours earlier--let me know whatever you think works best :) **Additional Exercises** _This section contains exercises selected from_ [Exercise Set C](http://www.dartmouth.edu/~chataway/Mathematics/_MATHEMATICS_EXERCISE_SET__CHATAWAY_.pdf) ****

subanswer.text: With replacement assumed, the joint probability equals product marginal ones giving $\frac{1}{\text{possible choices}} * \frac{1}{\text{poss Let me continue answering Question 5 for you now. To solve the problem assuming replacement—meaning once someone gets elected, they return back onto the roster so everyone still has an equal opportunity again—we use basic concepts from probability regarding combined independent events. In simpler terms, think about flipping a coin twice. Regardless of whether heads comes up or tails turns face down, the next throw behaves identically. Therefore, calculating separately allows combining them effortlessly later. Here, replacing means similar thinking applies but translated differently. 0.user_question: Two candidates, Dan and Donald, run for class president. Two other candidates, Freddie and Bernie, run for vice president. Each candidate has a 50$\%$ chance of winning. What is the probability that both Dan and Freddie win? (Express your answer as a fraction.)

direct_answer.text: There are four possible pairs of winners: DF, DB, FB, BD. For each pair, one person wins while another loses. There are therefore six equally likely ways someone could become either President or Vice President; thus it’s reasonable to assume any particular combination occurs half the time. Hence, P($\text{Dan} \, \& \text { Freddie }$) = P($\text{DF}$)/6 = ${1}/{6}$. To express our solution using just fractions without relying on reasoning about what “half” looks like relative to some imaginary set of possibilities, let us use combinatorics instead. Our sample space consists of ${4}\choose{2}$ ={4*3/2}=6 different ordered outcomes — we choose exactly 2 people who obtain positions among them without regard to order. Out of those six potential combinations, precisely one yields Daniel & Frederick victorious⁠ : the first such possibility would involve selecting Deacon first followed immediately by Fredrick – that corresponds to outcome ’DF.’ Thus Probability({DF}) =$ {\displaystyle {1\over6}}$. The answer is: \frac{1}{6}

0.user_question: Two candidates, Dan and Donald, run for class president. Two other candidates, Freddie and Bernie, run for vice president. Each candidate has a 50$\%$ chance of winning. What is the probability that both Dan and Freddie win? (Express your answer as a fraction.)

ost_step.1: There are four possible outcomes when electing one president and one vice president:

direct_answer.text: There are four people running for office -- three candidates for president ($Dan$, $Donald$) and two candidates for vice presidency ($Freddie$, $Bernie$). That makes sixteen different ways election results could turn out ($\binom{4}{1}*\binom{3}{1}=6$), since either one person fills each position; i.e., "$\binom{4}{1}\times \binom{3}{1}$". Half those possibilities give us what you seek - namely: President Daniel & Vice President Freddie OR President Donald & Vice President Freddie ; thus our required outcome count equals 3 ("six divided into twos"). To express it mathematically using fractions/probability notation: $$\dfrac{3}{\binom{4}{1}\cdot \binom{3}{1}}= \dfrac{3}{6}= \dfrac{1}{2}$$ Hence the correct choice among options available would definitely be 'C'. Thus, The Answer Is: \(\frac{1}{2}\).

direct_answer.text: To calculate the probability that both Dan and Freddie win, we need to consider each independent election separately because one person being elected does not affect the outcome of the other election. As stated, both elections occur independently and both candidates have a 50% chance of winning. Let D represent Dan winning and F represents Freddie winning. To satisfy our condition—both Dan and Freddie win—we look for P(D∩F): [P(D) * P(F)]=[(1/2)*(1/2)]=(1/4). Thus, the correct option here is {ⓐ} \(\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)\times\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)=\left(\frac{1}{4}\right)\) .
